{{Use American English|date=December 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} As a major [[developed economy]], the [[United States]] is highly dependent on the [[Internet]] and therefore greatly exposed to cyber attacks. At the same time, the United States has substantial capabilities in both defense and [[power projection]] thanks to its advanced technology and large [[Military budget of the United States|military budget]]. [[Cyberwarfare|Cyber warfare]] continues to be a growing threat to more physical systems and infrastructures that are linked to the internet. Malicious hacking from domestic or foreign enemies remains a constant threat to the United States. In response to these growing threats, the United States has developed significant cyber capabilities.
The [[United States Department of Defense]] recognizes the use of computers and the Internet to conduct warfare in [[cyberspace]] as a threat to [[national security]], but also as a platform for attack.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trump-cyberattack-directive-20_us_5b758f76e4b0df9b093d1b06|title=Trump Reverses Obama-Era Rules On Cyberattacks|last=Grenoble|first=Ryan|date=2018-08-16|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2018-10-01|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/us-military-cyberwar-2016-5|title=How the US military is beating hackers at their own game|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-10-01}}</ref>
The [[United States Cyber Command]] centralizes command of [[cyberspace]] operations, organizes existing cyber resources and synchronizes defense of U.S. military networks. It is an [[United States armed forces|armed forces]] [[Unified Combatant Command]].
== The Department of Defense Cyber Strategy == In April 2015, the U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) published its latest Cyber Strategy<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=US Department of Defense Cyber Strategy|last=|first=|publisher=US Department of Defense|year=2015|isbn=|location=http://www.defense.gov/Portals/1/features/2015/0415_cyber-strategy/Final_2015_DoD_CYBER_STRATEGY_for_web.pdf|pages=2–8}}</ref> building upon the previous DoD Strategy for Operating in Cyberspace published in July 2011.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Department of Defense Strategy for Operating In Cyberspace|last=|first=|publisher=US DoD|year=2011|isbn=|location=http://csrc.nist.gov/groups/SMA/ispab/documents/DOD-Strategy-for-Operating-in-Cyberspace.pdf|pages=}}</ref> The DoD Cyber strategy focuses on building capabilities to protect, secure, and defend its own DoD networks, systems and information; defend the nation against cyber attacks; and support [[contingency plan]]s. This includes being prepared to operate and continue to carry out missions in environments impacted by cyber attacks.
The DoD outlines three cyber missions: # Defend DoD networks, systems, and information. # Defend the United States and its interests against cyber attacks of significant consequence. # Provide integrated cyber capabilities to support military operations and contingency plans. In addition, the Cyber Strategy emphasizes the need to build bridges to the private sector, so that the best talent and technology the United States has to offer is at disposal to the DoD.<ref name=":0" />
=== The Five Pillars === {{quote box|quote=1. Build and maintain ready forces and capabilities to conduct cyberspace operations;
2. Defend the DoD information network, secure DoD data, and mitigate risks to DoD missions;
3. Be prepared to defend the U.S. homeland and U.S. vital interests from disruptive or destructive cyber attacks of significant consequence;
4. Build and maintain viable cyber options and plan to use those options to control conflict escalation and to shape the conflict environment at all stages;
5. Build and maintain robust international alliances and partnerships to deter shared threats and increase international security and stability.|source= —US Department of Defense Cyber Strategy, US DoD, April 2015.|align = center}}
The five pillars is the base of the Department of Defense's strategy for cyber warfare. The first pillar is to recognize that the new domain for warfare is [[cyberspace]] and that it is similar to the other elements in the [[battlespace]]. The key objectives of this pillar are to build up technical capabilities and accelerate research and development to provide the United States with a technological advantage. The second pillar is proactive defenses as opposed to passive defense. Two examples of passive defense are computer hygiene and [[Firewall (computing)|firewalls]]. The balance of the attacks requires active defense using sensors to provide a rapid response to detect and stop a cyber attack on a [[computer network]]. This would provide military tactics to backtrace, hunt down and attack an enemy intruder. The third pillar is [[critical infrastructure protection]] (CIP) to ensure the protection of critical infrastructure by developing warning systems to anticipate threats. The fourth pillar is the use of [[collective defense]] which would provide the ability of early detection, and incorporate it into the cyber warfare defense structure. The goal of this pillar is to explore all options in the face of a conflict, and to minimize loss of life and destruction of property. The fifth pillar is building and maintaining international alliances and partnerships to deter shared threats, and to remain adaptive and flexible to build new alliances as required. This is focused on "priority regions, to include the Middle East, Asia-Pacific, and Europe".<ref name=":0" />
=== Trump Administration's National Cyber Strategy === Shortly after his election, U.S. President Donald Trump pledged to deliver an extensive plan to improve U.S. cybersecurity within 90 days of his inauguration.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.networkworld.com/article/3190735/government/trumps-cybersecurity-mystery-90-days-in-wheres-the-plan.html|title=Trump's cybersecurity mystery: 90 days in, where's the plan?|last=Williams|first=Martyn|work=Network World|access-date=2018-10-02|language=en}}</ref> Three weeks after the designated 90-day mark, he signed an executive order that aim to strengthen government networks.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.the-parallax.com/2018/03/23/trump-cybersecurity-policy-worry/|title=Nonexistent Trump cybersecurity policy worries experts - The Parallax|date=2018-03-23|work=The Parallax|access-date=2018-10-02|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/presidential-executive-order-strengthening-cybersecurity-federal-networks-critical-infrastructure/|title=Presidential Executive Order on Strengthening the Cybersecurity of Federal Networks and Critical Infrastructure {{!}} The White House|work=The White House|access-date=2018-10-02|language=en-US}}</ref> By the new executive order, federal-agency leaders are to be held responsible for breaches on their networks and federal agencies are to follow the National Institute of Standards and Technology Framework for Improving Critical Infrastructure Cybersecurity in consolidating risk management practices. In addition, the federal departments were to examine cybersecurity defense abilities of agencies within 90 days, focusing on "risk mitigation and acceptance choices" and evaluating needs for funding and sharing technology across departments.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.the-parallax.com/2017/05/12/trump-cybersecurity-executive-order/|title=Trump's cybersecurity order not likely to have a major impact, experts say - The Parallax|date=2017-05-12|work=The Parallax|access-date=2018-10-02|language=en-US}}</ref>
In September, President Trump finally signed the National Cyber Strategy- "the first fully articulated cyber strategy for the United States since 2003."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/articles/president-trump-unveils-americas-first-cybersecurity-strategy-15-years/|title=President Trump Unveils America's First Cybersecurity Strategy in 15 Years {{!}} The White House|date=2018-09-20|work=The White House|access-date=2018-10-02|language=en-US}}</ref> John Bolton, the National Security Advisor, claimed in September 2018 that the Trump administration's new "National Cyber Strategy" has replaced restrictions on the use of offensive cyber operations with a legal regime that enables the Defense Department and other relevant agencies to operate with a greater authority to penetrate foreign networks to deter hacks on U.S. systems. Describing the new strategy as an endeavor to "create powerful deterrence structures that persuade the adversary not to strike in the first place," Bolton added that decision-making for launching attacks will be moved down the chain of command from requiring the president's approval.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2018/09/21/trump-has-a-new-weapon-to-cause-the-cyber-mayhem/|title=Trump Has a New Weapon to Cause 'the Cyber' Mayhem|last=Groll|first=Elias|website=Foreign Policy|language=en|access-date=2018-10-01}}</ref>
The Defense Department, in its strategy document released in September 2018, further announced that it would "defend forward" U.S. networks by disrupting "malicious cyber activity at its source" and endeavor to "ensure there are consequences for irresponsible cyber behavior" by "preserving peace through strength."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/president-donald-j-trump-is-strengthening-americas-cybersecurity/|title=President Donald J. Trump Is Strengthening America's Cybersecurity|work=The White House|access-date=2018-10-01|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Criticisms on the U.S. cyberdefense == The Trump administration was long criticized for delaying the release of a comprehensive cybersecurity strategy. The executive order on which the administration relied was complained to be absent of emphasis on securing the software supply chain and of adequate personnel to implement the cybersecurity guidelines.<ref name=":3" />
The new National Cyber Strategy has also garnered criticisms that evaluating acts of cyberwarfare against the United States still remains ambiguous, as the current U.S. law does not specifically define what constitutes an illegal cyberact that transcends a justifiable computer activity. The legal status of most information security research in the United States is governed by 1986 Computer Freud and Abuse Act (CFAA), which was derided to be "poorly drafted and arbitrarily enforced" by enabling prosecution of useful information security research methods such as Nmap or Shodan. As even the needed services fall into prohibition, top-level information security experts find it challenging to improve the infrastructure of cyberdefense.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2018/09/12/in-cyberwar-there-are-no-rules-cybersecurity-war-defense/|title=In Cyberwar, There are No Rules|last=Wheeler|first=Tarah|website=Foreign Policy|language=en|access-date=2018-10-01}}</ref>
==Cyberattack as an act of war== In 2011, [[The White House]] published an "International Strategy for Cyberspace" that reserved the right to use military force in response to a [[cyberattack]]:<ref>{{cite web|title=International Strategy for Cyberspace|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/rss_viewer/International_Strategy_Cyberspace_Factsheet.pdf|website=The White House|accessdate=4 September 2014|format=PDF|year=2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Alexander|first1=David|title=U.S. reserves right to meet cyber attack with force|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/16/us-usa-defense-cybersecurity-idUSTRE7AF02Y20111116|website=Reuters|accessdate=4 September 2014|date=15 November 2011}}</ref>
{{quote box|quote=When warranted, the United States will respond to hostile acts in cyberspace as we would to any other threat to our country. We reserve the right to use all necessary means — diplomatic, informational, military, and economic — as appropriate and consistent with applicable international law, in order to defend our Nation, our allies, our partners, and our interests. In so doing, we will exhaust all options before military force whenever we can; will carefully weigh the costs and risks of action against the costs of inaction; and will act in a way that reflects our values and strengthens our legitimacy, seeking broad international support whenever possible.|source= —International Strategy for Cyberspace, The White House, 2011}}
In 2013, the [[Defense Science Board]], an independent advisory committee to the [[U.S. Secretary of Defense]], went further, stating that "The cyber threat is serious, with potential consequences similar in some ways to the nuclear threat of the [[Cold War]]," and recommending, in response to the "most extreme case" (described as a "catastrophic full spectrum cyber attack"), that "Nuclear weapons would remain the ultimate response and anchor the deterrence ladder."<ref>{{cite web|url=|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|format=PDF|access-date=}}</ref>
==Attacks on other nations==
===Iran=== {{see also|Operation Olympic Games|Stuxnet}} In June 2010, Iran was the victim of a cyber attack when its nuclear facility in Natanz was infiltrated by the cyber-worm 'Stuxnet', said to be the most advanced piece of malware ever discovered and significantly increases the profile of cyberwarfare.<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hWP5Ga_K2k4oOosfMz39JFifrDaQ?docId=CNG.0c3a53ff7267f11501a5b3dbd9567dbf.2d1 AFP: Stuxnet worm brings cyber warfare out of virtual world]. Google.com (1 October 2010). Retrieved 8 November 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.ted.com/talks/ralph_langner_cracking_stuxnet_a_21st_century_cyberweapon.html Ralph Langner: Cracking Stuxnet, a 21st-century cyber weapon | Video on]. Ted.com. Retrieved 8 November 2011.</ref> It destroyed perhaps over 1,000 nuclear centrifuges and, according to a Business Insider article, "[set] Tehran's atomic program back by at least two years."<ref name="businessinsider.com">{{cite news |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/us-general-irans-cyber-war-machine-a-force-to-be-reckoned-with-2013-1 |title=US General: Iran's Cyber War Machine 'A Force To Be Reckoned With' |work=Business Insider|accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref>
Despite a lack of official confirmation, [[Gary Samore]], White House Coordinator for Arms Control and Weapons of Mass Destruction, made a public statement, in which he said, "we're glad they [the Iranians] are having trouble with their centrifuge machine and that we—the US and its allies—are doing everything we can to make sure that we complicate matters for them", offering "winking acknowledgement" of US involvement in Stuxnet.<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wnet/need-to-know/security/video-cracking-the-code-defending-against-the-superweapons-of-the-21st-century-cyberwar/9456/ Gary Samore] speaking at the 10 December 2010 Washington Forum of the [[Foundation for Defense of Democracies]] in Washington DC, reported by C-Span and contained in the PBS program Need to Know ([https://www.pbs.org/wnet/need-to-know/security/video-cracking-the-code-defending-against-the-superweapons-of-the-21st-century-cyberwar/9456/ "Cracking the code: Defending against the superweapons of the 21st century cyberwar"], 4 minutes into piece)</ref>
===China=== {{See also|PRISM (surveillance program)}}
In 2013, [[Edward Snowden]], a former systems administrator for the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] (CIA) and a counterintelligence trainer at the [[Defense Intelligence Agency]] (DIA), revealed that the United States government had hacked into Chinese mobile phone companies to collect text messages and had spied on [[Tsinghua University]], one of China's biggest research institutions, as well as home to one of China's six major backbone networks, the China Education and Research Network (CERNET), from where internet data from millions of Chinese citizens could be mined. He said U.S. spy agencies have been watching China and Hong Kong for years.<ref>{{cite web |last=Rapoza |first=Kenneth |title=U.S. Hacked China Universities, Mobile Phones, Snowden Tells China Press |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kenrapoza/2013/06/22/u-s-hacked-china-universities-mobile-phones-snowden-tells-china-press/ |publisher=Forbes |date= 2013-06-22}}</ref>
According to classified documents provided by [[Edward Snowden]], the [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) has also infiltrated the servers in the headquarters of [[Huawei]], China's largest telecommunications company and the largest telecommunications equipment maker in the world. The plan is to exploit Huawei's technology so that when the company sold equipment to other countries—including both allies and nations that avoid buying American products—the [[National Security Agency|NSA]] could roam through their computer and telephone networks to conduct surveillance and, if ordered by the president, offensive cyberoperations.<ref>{{cite web |first1=DAVID |last1=SANGER |first2=NICOLE |last2=PERLROTH |title=N.S.A. Breached Chinese Servers Seen as Security Threat| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/23/world/asia/nsa-breached-chinese-servers-seen-as-spy-peril.html?_r=1 |publisher=The New York Times |date=22 March 2014}}</ref>
===Other=== * In 1982, a computer control system stolen from a Canadian company by Soviet spies caused a Soviet gas pipeline to explode. It has been alleged that code for the control system had been modified by the CIA to include a [[logic bomb]] which changed the pump speeds to cause the explosion,<ref name="The New York Times; October 26, 2009">{{cite news|last=Markoff|first=John|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/27/science/27trojan.html?_r=1&ref=science&pagewanted=all|title=Cyberwar: Old Trick Threatens the Newest Weapons|work=The New York Times|date=26 October 2009|access-date=30 July 2015}}</ref><ref name="The New York Times; October 26, 2009"/><ref name="The New York Times; October 26, 2009"/><ref>{{cite news |newspaper=The Economist |url=http://www.economist.com/node/16478792?story_id=16478792&fsrc=rss |title=Cyberwar: War in the fifth domain |date=1 July 2010 |accessdate=4 July 2010 }}</ref> but this is disputed.<ref>{{cite news|first=Anatoly |last=Medetsky |url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/kgb-veteran-denies-cia-caused-82-blast/232261.html |title=KGB Veteran Denies CIA Caused '82 Blast|newspaper=Moscow Times |date=18 March 2004 |access-date=30 July 2015}}</ref><ref name="Bloomberg Business; October 10, 2014">{{cite news |last1=Hesseldahl |first1=Arik |author-link1=Arik Hesseldahl |last2=Kharif |first2=Olga |date=10 October 2014 |title=Cyber Crime and Information Warfare: A 30-Year History |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/ss/10/10/1014_cyber_attacks/1.htm |newspaper=Bloomberg Business |page=2 |access-date=30 July 2015}}</ref> * A 1 April 1991 article in [[InfoWorld]] Magazine ''"Meta-Virus Set to Unleash Plague on Windows 3.0 Users"'' by John Gantz<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0FAEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA39&lpg=PA39&dq=Virus+AF+91&source=bl&ots=ZygnpUz-XZ&sig=ndjx0hthBv2xdSP0PcniA7zNKVo&hl=en&ei=xLjcSsm0FImnlAf2zq2hAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CBUQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=Virus%20AF%2091&f=false|title=Tech Street|first=John|last=Gantz|publisher=[[InfoWorld]]|date=1 April 1991|accessdate=13 November 2015}}</ref> was purported to be an extremely early example of [[cyber warfare]] between 2 countries. In fact the "[[AF/91]] virus" was an April Fools Joke that was misunderstood and widely re-reported as fact by credulous media.<ref name="SecurityFocus">{{cite web|url=http://www.securityfocus.com/columnists/147|title=Iraqi Cyberwar: an Ageless Joke|first=George|last=Smith|publisher=SecurityFocus|date=10 March 2003|accessdate=13 November 2015}}</ref>
==Cyber threat information sharing== The Pentagon has had an information sharing arrangement, the Defense Industrial Base Cybersecurity and Information Assurance (DIBCIA) program, in place with some private defense contractors since 2007<ref>[http://fcw.com/articles/2014/04/22/dod-infosharing-pilot.aspx "Increased trust boosts Pentagon-industry info sharing"], Sean Lyngaas, 22 April 2014, FCW.com</ref> to which access was widened in 2012.<ref>Reed, John. [https://foreignpolicy.com/2012/09/27/pentagon-expanding-public-private-cyber-information-sharing-program/ "Pentagon expanding public-private cyber information sharing program."] ''Foreign Policy Magazine'', 27 September 2012.</ref>
A number of other information sharing initiatives such as the [[Cyber Intelligence Sharing and Protection Act]] (CISPA) and [[Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act]] (CISA) have been proposed, but failed for various reasons including over fears that they have too few limits, and could be used to spy on the general public.
==United States Cyber Command== The [[United States Cyber Command]] (USCYBERCOM) is a [[United States Armed Forces]] [[Unified Combatant Command]]. USCYBERCOM plans, coordinates, integrates, synchronizes and conducts activities to: defend Department of Defense information networks and; prepare to conduct "full spectrum military cyberspace operations" to ensure US/Allied freedom of action in cyberspace and deny the same to adversaries.<ref>U.S. Department of Defense, Cyber Command Fact Sheet, 21 May 2010 {{cite web |url=http://www.stratcom.mil/factsheets/cc/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-09-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100905140740/http://www.stratcom.mil/factsheets/cc |archivedate=5 September 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Army=== The [[U.S. Army Cyber Command|Army Cyber Command]] (ARCYBER) is an Army component command for the [[United States Cyber Command|U.S. Cyber Command]].<ref name="Release">{{cite web|url=http://www.defense.gov//releases/release.aspx?releaseid=13549 |title=DoD Release No. 420-10 Establishment of Army Forces Cyber Command |author=US Department of Defense |date=24 May 2010 |work= |publisher=defense.gov |accessdate=24 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110529013300/http://www.defense.gov//news/newsarticle.aspx?id=63635 |archivedate=29 May 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> ARCYBER has the following components: * [[Army Network Enterprise Technology Command (NETCOM)/9th Army Signal Command|Army Network Enterprise Technology Command / 9th Army Signal Command]] * Portions of [[1st Information Operations Command (Land)]] * [[United States Army Intelligence and Security Command]] will be under the operational control of ARCYBER for cyber-related actions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oss.net/dynamaster/file_archive/091203/a53921426defcb651c95437bba2d54f5/20091203%20IO%20Newsletter%20v10%20no%2003.doc |title=20091203 IO Newsletter v10 no 03 |date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Patrick Jackson |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/8511711.stm |title=Meet USCybercom: Why the US is fielding a cyber army |publisher=BBC News |date=15 March 2010 |accessdate=10 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defense.gov//releases/release.aspx?releaseid=13549 |title=News Release: Army Forces Cyber Command Headquarters Standup Plan Announced |publisher=Defense.gov |date= |accessdate=10 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110529013300/http://www.defense.gov//news/newsarticle.aspx?id=63635 |archivedate=29 May 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref>
===Marine Corps=== [[United States Marine Corps Forces Cyberspace Command]] is a functional formation of the [[United States Marine Corps]] to protect infrastructure from [[cyberwarfare]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ftmeade.army.mil/pages/news/stories/2010/jan/cyber.html |title=Fort Mead News: USMC Cyber Command |publisher=Ftmeade.army.mil |date=28 January 2010 |accessdate=10 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100413135334/http://www.ftmeade.army.mil/pages/news/stories/2010/jan/cyber.html |archivedate=13 April 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Air Force=== The [[Twenty-Fourth Air Force]] ('''24 AF''') will be the [[United States Air Force]] component of [[United States Cyber Command]] (USCYBER).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afcyber.af.mil/library/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=10688|title=Frequently Asked Questions|publisher=}}</ref> It has the following components: *[[67th Network Warfare Wing]] *[[688th Information Operations Wing]] *[[689th Combat Communications Wing]]
===Navy=== The [[Navy Cyber Forces]] (CYBERFOR) is the type commander for the U.S. Navy's global cyber workforce. The headquarters is located at Joint Expeditionary Base Little Creek-Fort Story. CYBERFOR provides forces and equipment in cryptology/signals intelligence, cyber, electronic warfare, information operations, intelligence, networks, and space. In September 2013, the [[United States Naval Academy]] will offer undergraduate students the opportunity to major in Cyber Operations.<ref>{{cite web|author=Mike Hoffman |url=http://defensetech.org/2013/06/08/naval-academy-launches-cyber-operations-major/ |title=Naval Academy Launches Cyber Operations Major |publisher=DefenseTech.org |date=8 June 2013}}</ref>
[[U.S. Fleet Cyber Command|Fleet Cyber Command]] is an [[Structure of the United States Navy#Operating forces|operating force]] of the [[United States Navy]] responsible for the Navy's cyber warfare programs.<ref>DOD News Release [http://www.defenselink.mil//releases/release.aspx?releaseid=13071 827-09]</ref> [[United States Tenth Fleet|Tenth]] [[Naval fleet|Fleet]] is a force provider for Fleet Cyber Command.<ref>Navy Stands Up Fleet Cyber Command, Reestablishes U.S. 10th Fleet, [http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=50954 NNS100129-24]</ref> The fleet components are: *[[Naval Network Warfare Command]] *[[Navy Cyber Defense Operations Command]] *[[Naval Information Operation Commands]] *[[Combined Task Forces]]
==Timeline== [[File:Monitoring a simulated test at Central Control Facility at Eglin Air Force Base (080416-F-5297K-101).jpg|thumb|<center>Cyberwar defense team</center>]]
*Systems in the US military and private research institutions were penetrated from March 1998 for almost two years in an incident called [[Moonlight Maze]]. The [[United States Department of Defense]] traced the trail back to a mainframe computer in the former Soviet Union but the sponsor of the attacks is unknown and Russia denies any involvement. *[[Titan Rain]] was the [[U.S. government]]'s designation given to a series of coordinated attacks on American computer systems since 2003. The attacks were labeled as Chinese in origin, although their precise nature (i.e., [[state-sponsored espionage]], [[corporate espionage]], or random [[Hacker (computer security)|hacker]] attacks) and their real identities (i.e., masked by proxy, zombie computer, spyware/virus infected) remain unknown. *In 2007, the United States government suffered "an espionage [[Attack on Pearl Harbor|Pearl Harbor]]" in which an unknown foreign power ... broke into all of the high tech agencies, all of the military agencies, and downloaded terabytes of information.<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/11/06/60minutes/main5555565.shtml | work=CBS News | title=Cyber War: Sabotaging the System | date=6 November 2009}}</ref> *In 2008, a hacking incident occurred on a U.S. Military facility in the Middle East. [[United States Deputy Secretary of Defense]] [[William J. Lynn III]] had the [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]] release a document, which reflected a "malicious code" on a [[USB flash drive]] spread undetected on both [[classified information|classified]] and [[unclassified]] Pentagon systems, establishing a digital [[beachhead]], from which data could be transferred to servers under foreign control. "It was a network administrator's worst fear: a rogue program operating silently, poised to deliver operational plans into the hands of an unknown adversary. This ... was the most significant breach of U.S. military computers ever and it served as an important wake-up call", Lynn wrote in an article for [[Foreign Affairs]].<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/25/AR2010082504588.html The Washington Post: Pentagon computers attacked with flash drive]{{dead link|date=June 2013}}</ref> *On 9 February 2009, the [[White House]] announced that it will conduct a review of the nation's cyber security to ensure that the [[Federal government of the United States]] cyber security initiatives are appropriately integrated, resourced and coordinated with the [[United States Congress]] and the private sector.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/blogs/2009/02/09/politics/politicalhotsheet/entry4788180.shtml |title=White House Eyes Cyber Security Plan |publisher=CBS News |date=9 February 2009}}</ref> *On 1 April 2009, U.S. lawmakers pushed for the appointment of a White House cyber security "czar" to dramatically escalate U.S. defenses against cyber attacks, crafting proposals that would empower the government to set and enforce security standards for private industry for the first time.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/03/31/AR2009033103684.html |title=Senate Legislation Would Federalize Cybersecurity |publisher=Washingtonpost.com |date= 1 April 2009|first1=Joby |last1=Warrick |first2=Walter |last2=Pincus}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://theintercept.com/2014/03/12/nsa-plans-infect-millions-computers-malware/ |title=How the NSA Plans to Infect 'Millions' of Computers with Malware |publisher=The Intercept |date= 2014-03-12|first1=Glenn |last1=Greenwald |first2=Ryan |last2=Gallagher }}</ref>
*On 7 April 2009, [[The Pentagon]] announced they spent more than $100 million in the last six months responding to and repairing damage from cyber attacks and other computer network problems.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/04/07/tech/main4926071.shtml |title=Pentagon Bill To Fix Cyber Attacks: $100M |publisher=CBS News |date=7 April 2009}}</ref> *From December 2009 to January 2010, a cyber attack, dubbed [[Operation Aurora]], was launched from China against [[Google]] and over 20 other companies.<ref name="googleblog">{{cite web|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2010/01/new-approach-to-china.html|title=A new approach to China|date=12 January 2010|publisher=[[Blogspot]] |accessdate=17 January 2010}}</ref> Google said the attacks originated from China and that it would "review the feasibility" of its business operations in China following the incident. According to Google, at least 20 other companies in various sectors had been targeted by the attacks. [[McAfee]] spokespersons claimed that "this is the highest profile attack of its kind that we have seen in recent memory."<ref name=McAfee>[http://siblog.mcafee.com/cto/google-attack-is-tip-of-iceberg/ "Google Attack Is Tip Of Iceberg"], McAfee Security Insights, 13 January 2010</ref> *In February 2010, the [[United States Joint Forces Command]] released a study which included a summary of the threats posed by the internet: "The open and free flow of information favored by the West will allow adversaries an unprecedented ability to gather intelligence."<ref name=JOE>[https://web.archive.org/web/20130810043238/http://www.jfcom.mil/newslink/storyarchive/2010/JOE_2010_o.pdf "The Joint Operating Environment"], Report released, 18 Feb 2010, pp. 34–36</ref> *On 19 June 2010, United States Senator [[Joe Lieberman]] (I-CT) introduced a bill called "Protecting Cyberspace as a National Asset Act of 2010",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hsgac.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?FuseAction=Files.View&FileStore_id=4ee63497-ca5b-4a4b-9bba-04b7f4cb0123|title=Home - Homeland Security & Governmental Affairs Committee|website=hsgac.senate.gov}}</ref> which he co-wrote with Senator [[Susan Collins]] (R-ME) and Senator [[Thomas Carper]] (D-DE). If signed into law, this controversial bill, which the American media dubbed the "''[[Kill switch#Cybersecurity policy|Kill switch bill]]''", would grant the [[President of the United States|President]] emergency powers over parts of the Internet. However, all three co-authors of the bill issued a statement that instead, the bill "[narrowed] existing broad Presidential authority to take over telecommunications networks".<ref name="nokillswitch">[http://www.informationweek.com/news/government/security/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=225701368&subSection=News Senators Say Cybersecurity Bill Has No 'Kill Switch'], informationweek.com, 24 June 2010. Retrieved on 25 June 2010.</ref> *In August 2010, the U.S. for the first time publicly warned about the Chinese military's use of civilian computer experts in clandestine cyber attacks aimed at American companies and government agencies. [[The Pentagon]] also pointed to an alleged China-based computer spying network dubbed [[GhostNet]] that was revealed in a research report last year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defense.gov/pubs/pdfs/2010_CMPR_Final.pdf |title=ANNUAL REPORT TO CONGRESS Military and Security Developments Involving the People's Republic of China 2010 |format=PDF |date=}}</ref> The Pentagon stated that the [[People's Liberation Army]] was using "information warfare units" to develop [[Computer virus|viruses]] to attack enemy computer systems and networks, and those units include civilian computer professionals. Commander [[Bob Mehal]] would monitor the PLA's buildup of its cyberwarfare capabilities and "will continue to develop capabilities to counter any potential threat."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/washington/articles/2010/08/19/pentagon_takes_aim_at_china_cyber_threat/|title=Pentagon takes aim at China cyber threat|first=Lolita C.|last=Baldor|date=19 August 2010|publisher=|via=The Boston Globe}}</ref> In response to these and other clandestine cyber attacks by China, [[Amitai Etzioni]] of the Institute for Communitarian Policy Studies had suggested that China and the United States should agree to a policy of mutually assured restraint with respect to cyberspace. This would involve allowing both states to take the measures they deem necessary for their self-defense while simultaneously agreeing to refrain from taking offensive steps; it would also entail vetting these commitments.<ref>{{cite news | last=Etzioni | first=Amitai | title=MAR: A Model for US-China Relations | work=The Diplomat | date=20 September 2013 | url=http://thediplomat.com/2013/09/mar-a-model-for-us-china-relations/ | accessdate=2 December 2015}}</ref> * In 2010, American General [[Keith B. Alexander]] endorsed talks with Russia over a proposal to limit military attacks in cyberspace, representing a significant shift in U.S. policy.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052748703340904575284964215965730 |title=WSJ: U.S. Backs Talks on Cyber Warfare |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=4 June 2010}}</ref> * In 2011 as part of [[Timeline of events involving Anonymous#Attack on HBGary Federal|The Anonymous attack on HBGary Federal]] information about private companies such as [[Endgame systems]] who design offensive software for the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] were revealed. It was shown that Endgame systems job applicants had previously "managed team of 15 persons, responsible for coordinating offensive computer network operations for the United States Department of Defense and other federal agencies."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/03/20113981026464808.html|title= Lessons from Anonymous on cyberwar |author=Haroon Meer|date= 11 March 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera English}}</ref> * In October 2012, the Pentagon was to host contractors who "want to propose revolutionary technologies for understanding, planning and managing cyberwarfare. It is part of an ambitious program that the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, or DARPA, calls Plan X, and the public description talks about 'understanding the cyber battlespace', quantifying 'battle damage' and working in DARPA's 'cyberwar laboratory.'"<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/27/us/us-officials-opening-up-on-cyberwarfare.html |title=U.S. Officials Opening Up on Cyberwarfare | work=The New York Times | first=Scott |last=Shane |date=26 September 2012}}</ref> * Starting in September 2012, [[Distributed denial of service attack|denial of service attacks]], were carried out against the [[New York Stock Exchange]] and a number of banks including [[J.P. Morgan Chase]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.foxbusiness.com/industries/2012/09/19/chase-website-experiences-intermittent-troubles/ | title = Chase, NYSE Websites Targeted in Cyber Attacks. | accessdate =15 March 2013}}</ref> Credit for these attacks was claimed by a [[hacktivist]] group called the Qassam Cyber Fighters<ref>{{cite web | url = http://pastebin.com/E4f7fmB5 | title = Phase 2 Operation Ababil. | accessdate =15 March 2013}}</ref> who have labeled the attacks [[Operation Ababil]]. The attacks had been executed in several phases and were restarted in March 2013.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.informationweek.com/security/attacks/bank-attackers-restart-operation-ababil/240150175 | title = Bank Attackers Restart Operation Ababil DDoS Disruptions. | accessdate =15 March 2013}}</ref> * In 2013, the first Tallinn Manual on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Warfare<ref>{{Cite book|title = Tallinn Manual|last = NATO Cooperative Cyber Defence Centre of Excellence|first = |publisher = Cambridge University Press|year = 2013|isbn = 978-1-107-02443-4|location = http://issuu.com/nato_ccd_coe/docs/tallinnmanual/1|pages = }}</ref> was published. This publication was the result of an independent study to examine and review laws governing cyber warfare sponsored by the NATO Cooperative Cyber Defence Centre of Excellence in 2009. * In February 2013, the White House Presidential Executive Order (E.o.) 13636 "Improving Critical Infrastructure Cybersecurity<ref>{{Cite web|title = Executive Order -- Improving Critical Infrastructure Cybersecurity|url = https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2013/02/12/executive-order-improving-critical-infrastructure-cybersecurity|website = whitehouse.gov|accessdate = 2015-10-25}}</ref>" was published. This executive order highlighted the policies needed to improve and coordinate cybersecurity, identification of critical infrastructure, reduction of cyber risk, information sharing with the private sector, and ensure civil and privacy liberties protections are incorporated. * In January 2014, the White House Presidential Policy Directive 28 (PPD-28) on "Signals Intelligence Activities<ref>{{Cite web|title = Presidential Policy Directive -- Signals Intelligence Activities|url = https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/01/17/presidential-policy-directive-signals-intelligence-activities|website = whitehouse.gov|accessdate = 2015-10-25}}</ref>" was published. This presidential policy directive highlighted the principles, limitations of use, process of collection, safeguarding of personal information, and transparency related to the collection and review of cyber intelligence signal activities. * In August 2014, "gigabytes" of sensitive data were reported stolen from JPMorgan Chase, and the company's internal investigation was reported to have found that the data was sent to a "major Russian city." The FBI was said to be investigating whether the breach was in retaliation for sanctions the United States had imposed on Russia in relation to the [[2014 Russian military intervention in Ukraine]].<ref>{{cite web|author1=Michael Riley|author2=Jordan Robertson|title=FBI Examining Whether Russia Is Tied to JPMorgan Hacking|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-08-27/fbi-said-to-be-probing-whether-russia-tied-to-jpmorgan-hacking.html|website=Bloomberg|accessdate=5 September 2014|date=27 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Jordan Robertson|author2=Michael Riley|title=Computers for Hire Send JPMorgan Data to Russia|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-09-04/computers-for-hire-said-to-send-jpmorgan-data-to-russia.html|website=Bloomberg|accessdate=5 September 2014|date=3 September 2014}}</ref> * On 29 May 2014, iSIGHT Partners uncovered a "long-term" and "unprecedented" cyber espionage that was "the most elaborate cyber espionage campaign using [[social engineering (security)|social engineering]] that has been uncovered to date from any nation". Labelled "[[Operation Newscaster]]", it targeted senior U.S. military and diplomatic personnel, congresspeople, journalists, lobbyists, think tankers and defense contractors, including a [[Admiral (United States)|four-star admiral]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/29/iran-hackers-idUSL1N0OE2CU20140529|editor=Tiffany Wu|first=Jim |last=Finkle|title=Iranian hackers use fake Facebook accounts to spy on U.S., others|date=29 May 2014|accessdate=30 March 2015|work=[[Reuters]]}}</ref> * In December 2014, Cylance Inc. published an investigation on so-called "[[Operation Cleaver]]" which targeted over 50 world's unnamed leading enterprises, including in United States. [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] tacitly acknowledged the operation and "warned businesses to stay vigilant and to report any suspicious activity spotted on the companies' computer systems".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-12-02/iran-backed-hackers-target-airports-carriers-report|first= Michael A |last=Riley |first2= Jordan |last2=Robertson |title= Iran-Backed Hackers Target Airports, Carriers: Report |date=2 December 2014 |accessdate=30 March 2015|work=[[Bloomberg News]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/12/02/us-cybersecurity-iran-idUSKCN0JG18I20141202|editor=Richard Valdmanis, Christian Plumb and W Simon|first=Jim |last=Finkle|title=Iran hackers targeted airlines, energy firms: report|date=2 December 2014 |accessdate=30 March 2015|work=[[Reuters]]}}</ref> * In December 2014, in response to a hack on the US based company Sony believed to be perpetrated by North Korea (see [[Sony Pictures hack]]) the US government created new economic sanctions on North Korea and listed the country as a state sponsor of terrorism. After the hack, there was an internet blackout over most of North Korea allegedly caused by the US, but there was no definitive evidence to support that claim.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/3652479/sony-hack-north-korea-the-interview-obama-sanctions/|title=U.S. Sanctions North Korea Over Sony Hack|website=Time|access-date=2017-04-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-30586940|title=Why did North Korea's internet go down?|last=Evans|first=Stephen|date=2014-12-23|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-04-09|language=en-GB}}</ref> * In April 2015, The Department of Defense Cyber Strategy<ref name=":0" /> was updated and published. Original DoD Strategy for Operating In Cyberspace<ref name=":1" /> was published in July 2011. * In 2015 the [[United States Office of Personnel Management]] (OPM) was victim to what has been described by federal officials as [[Office of Personnel Management data breach|among the largest breaches of government data in the history of the United States]],<ref name=wsj>{{cite web | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-suspects-hackers-in-china-behind-government-data-breach-sources-say-1433451888 | title=U.S. Suspects Hackers in China Breached About four (4) Million People's Records, Officials Say | work=Wall Street Journal | date=5 June 2015 | accessdate=5 June 2015 | author=Barrett, Devlin}}</ref> in which an estimated 21.5 million records were stolen. Information targeted in the breach included [[personally identifiable information]] such as [[Social Security number]]s,<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/06/05/china-suspected-in-theft-of-federal-employee-records | title=China Suspected in Theft of Federal Employee Records | work=US News & World Report | date=5 June 2015 | accessdate=5 June 2015 | author=Risen, Tom}}</ref> as well as names, dates and places of birth, and addresses,<ref name=npr>{{cite web | url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2015/06/04/412086068/massive-data-breach-puts-4-million-federal-employees-records-at-risk | title=Massive Data Breach Puts 4 Million Federal Employees' Records At Risk | work=NPR | date=4 June 2015 | accessdate=5 June 2015 | author=Sanders, Sam}}</ref> and likely involved theft of detailed background security-clearance-related background information. * In June 2015, the US Department of Defense (DoD) included a chapter dedicated to cyber warfare in the DoD Law of War Manual.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title = Department of Defense Law of War|last = |first = |publisher = US Department of Defense|year = 2015|isbn = |location = http://www.dod.mil/dodgc/images/law_war_manual15.pdf|pages = 994}}</ref> See Cyber Warfare section on p. 994.<ref name=":2"/> * In 2016 Cyber Command mounted computer-network attacks on ISIL.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/25/us/politics/us-directs-cyberweapons-at-isis-for-first-time.html |title=ISIS Targeted by Cyberattacks in a New U.S. Line of Combat |publisher=NYT |date=24 April 2016}}</ref> *In March 2018, the Office of Foreign Assets Control sanctioned two Russian intelligence agencies, the Federal Security Service (FSB) and the Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) for committing "destructive cyber-attacks." The attacks include the NotPetya attack, an assault that was allegedly conducted by the Russian military in February according to statements of the White House and British government, and which the United States Treasury described as "the most destructive and costly cyber-attack in history."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/democracy-in-america/2018/03/15/america-sanctions-russians-for-election-meddling-and-cyber-attacks|title=America sanctions Russians for election-meddling and cyber-attacks|work=The Economist|access-date=2018-10-01|language=en}}</ref> *In March 2018, the United States Justice Department charged nine Iranians with stealing scientific secrets on behalf of Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps. The defendants "stole more than 31 terabytes of academic data and intellectual property from universities, and email accounts of employees at private sector companies, government agencies, and non-governmental organizations."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/nine-iranians-charged-conducting-massive-cyber-theft-campaign-behalf-islamic-revolutionary|title=Nine Iranians Charged With Conducting Massive Cyber Theft Campaign on Behalf of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps|date=2018-03-23|access-date=2018-10-01|language=en}}</ref> *In September 2018, the United States Justice Department published a criminal complaint against Park Jin Hyok, a professional hacker alleged to be working for North Korea's military intelligence bureau, for his commitment of three cyber-attacks: attack against Sony Pictures in 2014, the theft of $81m from the central bank of Bangladesh in 2016, and WannaCry 2.0 ransomware attack against hundreds of thousands of computers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/united-states/2018/09/13/americas-government-is-putting-foreign-cyber-spies-in-the-dock|title=America's government is putting foreign cyber-spies in the dock|work=The Economist|access-date=2018-10-01|language=en}}</ref>
